message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest aortic stenosis. Among the options provided, only a paradoxically split S2 is commonly associated with aortic stenosis. A wide and fixed split S2 is commonly associated with atrial septal defect, a constant, machine-like murmur heard between the scapulae is commonly associated with patent ductus arteriosus, and a diastolic murmur heard at the cardiac apex is commonly associated with mitral stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings suggest aortic stenosis. A paradoxically split S2 is commonly associated with aortic stenosis due to delayed closure of the aortic valve. Options A, B, and D are not typically associated with aortic stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard over the right sternal border with radiation to the carotids is consistent with aortic stenosis. A paradoxically split S2 is commonly found in aortic stenosis due to the delayed closure of the aortic valve. A wide and fixed split S2 is seen in conditions like atrial septal defect, while a constant, machine-like murmur heard between the scapulae is heard in patent ductus arteriosus. A diastolic murmur heard at the cardiac apex is a sign of aortic regurgitation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including shortness of breath and chest discomfort, suggest aortic stenosis. The harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard over the right sternal border with radiation to the carotids is indicative of aortic stenosis, and the paradoxically split S2 is a common finding in patients with aortic stenosis as the aortic valve closes later than the pulmonary valve. Options A, B, and D do not fit with the typical presentation of aortic stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the physical exam findings suggest aortic stenosis, which can cause a paradoxically split S2 due to delayed closure of aortic valve. Option A is seen in pulmonary hypertension. Option B is seen in patent ductus arteriosus. Option D is seen in mitral stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard over the right sternal border with radiation to the carotids suggests aortic stenosis, which is most commonly associated with a paradoxically split S2. Option A (wide and fixed split S2) is associated with atrial septal defect, option B (machine-like murmur) is associated with patent ductus arteriosus, and option D (diastolic murmur at the cardiac apex) is associated with mitral stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination are consistent with aortic stenosis, which often presents with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard over the right sternal border, with radiation to the carotids. Paradoxical splitting of S2 is common in aortic stenosis due to the prolonged ejection period. Other options are not expected to be found in aortic stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the murmur indicates aortic stenosis, which is commonly associated with a paradoxically split S2. A wide and fixed split S2 suggests a atrial septal defect or right bundle branch block. A constant, machine-like murmur heard between the scapulae suggests patent ductus arteriosus. A diastolic murmur heard at the cardiac apex suggests aortic regurgitation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of shortness of breath and chest discomfort with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard over the right sternal border with radiation to carotids suggests aortic stenosis. A paradoxically split S2 is commonly seen in severe aortic stenosis due to delayed closure of the aortic valve. Options A, B, and D are not typically associated with aortic stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and the murmur suggest aortic stenosis. A paradoxically split S2 is a common finding in aortic stenosis due to prolonged ejection time of the right ventricle. A wide and fixed split S2 is associated with atrial septal defect. A constant, machine-like murmur heard between the scapulae is associated with patent ductus arteriosus. A diastolic murmur heard at the cardiac apex is associated with mitral regurgitation.
